page.title: 05Bredfield Church
page.content: Outside St. Andrew's church porch which is big with seats along the inside, there is a black foot scraper. Some of the pews have poppy heads on the ends. The hammerbeam roof is also carved. The stone font at the back of the church has eight sides with some lovely patterns on and it is one hundred and twelve years old. There is a baptismal roll. On the wall inside there is a brass of Leonard Farrington and his wife with their children, six boys and two girls. Each hassock has a different British flower embroidered on it by local needlewomen. The lectern is brass and shaped like an eagle standing on a ball. There is an organ near the altar. The church and bottom of the tower are built of flint. Old wills state that the tower was being built in 1452, but a red brick top was added in Tudor times.
